Award.AwardTitle: Hurricane Surge and Wave Loads on Near-Coast Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane storms such as Sandy and Typhoon Haiyan in the Philippines have caused catastrophic damage. In the near-coast region, a large amount of this damage has been from wave and surge impacting buildings and other structures. Currently there are criteria for surge and wave loads that are used for design. However, standard empirical loads neglect the effects of unsteady wave and surge processes, which can lead to much larger loads in the immediate vicinity of the shoreline. This project will pursue fundamental research into the nature of these unsteady structural loads, and how they affect buildings. Computational simulation backed up by case studies from Hurricane Sandy and Super Typhoon Haiyan in Philippines will develop and test representations for near-coast structural loading from unsteady waves and surge. Results will allow engineers and planners for better designs as they work to reduce damages from future hurricanes.

The neglect of unsteady radiation stresses in standard phase-averaged wave and surge models results in underestimation of maximum wave heights and current velocities in the near-coast region, and the neglect of bore-like loading. This can lead to severe underestimates of structural design loads. The research team will examine these processes using Boussinesq and Navier-Stokes fluid mechanics models to (1) map regions where low-frequency hydrodynamic processes are significant; (2) establish relationships between hydrodynamic properties and associated structural loading for canonical geometries; and (3) synthesize these results for design purposes. Loads will be subdivided into impact and quasi-steady categories, with different analyses and synthesis for each. The hypothesis that specific momentum flux is proportional to loading will be tested closely, as this may provide a relatively simple method to incorporate many of these processes into structural loading parameterizations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigated wave loads on near-coast structures and how these loads vary in time and space. Work was performed with laboratory experiments, with numerical models, and during field work.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

Laboratory experiments work performed here showed how wave loads are affected by sheltering from upstream structures, and how rapid and slow inundation further affect loading. Results show that the greatest decrease in loading occurs after one sheltering layer, with relatively smaller decreases as additional sheltering is added. 

 

Work examining horizontal and vertical wave loads on near-coast structures show that breaking and near-breaking waves provide the largest loads, with peak vertical loading exceeding peak horizontal loading in many cases. However, vertical loads decrease much more rapidly from their peak than do horizontal loads. For structural components like wall elements with rapid response times, this means that peak loads must be considered, but components that respond on longer time scales, such as an overall structural framing system, may use significantly lower loading.

 

Finally, considerable effort was spent in developing and testing methods to reverse-estimate the wave and loading climate during a storm from the motion of heavy objects. These objects were usually boulders or concrete blocks, and could be very large – more than 8m long and 200 tonnes in the most severe cases. Detailed fieldwork, numerical models, and theoretical advances helped to determine the conditions experienced during these storms, with error estimates.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The work performed during this project has direct relevance to engineering loading standards, and will prove useful in planned future standard revisions. It is also proving a useful starting point for continuing work on improving engineering loading prediction.

 

Four graduate students worked on this project, some funded directly by the grant, and others by the NSF Graduate Fellowship Research Program. International collaborations with Japanese universities helped to boost some of the research; further collaborations with American, Japanese, and European researchers have been initiated following the success of the post-storm evaluation of storm conditions from boulder motion.
